_comment: This data is an early work-in-progress and contains errors. Produced by @michaelh at Discuss and Discover SuttaCentral forum - please get in touch! Finished code forthcoming.

The two types of mendicants and their wo: Mendicants who are perfected, with defilements ended, having completed the spiritual journey, done what had to be done, laid down the burden, achieved their own goal, utterly ended the fetters of rebirth, and become rightly freed through enlightenment
Mendicants who are trainees, who haven’t achieved their heart’s desire, but live aspiring to the supreme sanctuary
The six fields of contact (a causal sequ: Sights known by the eye that are pleasant
Sights known by the eye that are unpleasant
Sounds known by the ear that are pleasant
Sounds known by the ear that are unpleasant
Smells known by the nose that are pleasant
Smells known by the nose that are unpleasant
Tastes known by the tongue that are pleasant
Tastes known by the tongue that are unpleasant
Touches known by the body that are pleasant
Touches known by the body that are unpleasant
Thoughts known by the mind that are pleasant
Thoughts known by the mind that are unpleasant
The qualities of mendicants who have wor: Their energy is roused up and unflagging
Their mindfulness is established and lucid
Their body is tranquil and undisturbed
Their mind is immersed in samādhi
